awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Spin Plasmonics for Ultrafast All-Optical Manipulation of Magnetization in Hybrid Metal-Ferromagnet Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description: Efficient computation, information processing and digital communications rely on technologies utilizing magnetic materials. Recent work has shown that optical laser pulses can be used to manipulate magnetic material properties, promising access to stored data at breakthrough speeds, significantly faster than in current computing devices. However, the fundamental mechanism of this process, as well as the limit to size of the individual memory units are not yet fully understood. This project aims to realize optical control over magnetic memory at unprecedented speed and density, using hybrid materials comprising metallic and magnetic nanostructures. The intertwined optical, thermal and magnetic effects in these materials are examined through a set of experimental and computational studies. The proposed work stands to impact society in multiple ways. Ultrafast, nanoscale optical control of magnetic materials enables data storage, memory and computational devices for applications such as web search engines and online commerce. The integrated education plan incorporates significant outreach, involving students beginning from grades 7-12 to the graduate level. Participating students are exposed to several rapidly growing fields including materials science, optics, and nanotechnology, while additionally interacting with industrial collaborators.

Technical Description: All-optical switching of magnetization has emerged as an exciting topic in modern magnetism. In addition to the requirement of fully understanding its rich physics, all-optical switching must compete with the areal densities attainable in current storage devices for it to be technologically compelling. The goal of this project is to utilize a new class of hybrid materials consisting of noble metals and ferromagnets, where the exceptional field confinement and strong optical spin of surface plasmons are leveraged to realize nanoscale ultrafast all-optical switching of magnetization. The synergistic research and education activities include: (1) achieving manipulation of out-of-plane and in-plane magnetization using optical spins of surface plasmons; (2) investigating the dynamics of different carriers and their interactions in hybrid metal-ferromagnet structures; (3) gaining new insights into the mechanism of nanoscale, ultrafast magnetization reversal; and (4) engaging students, especially those from underrepresented groups, and educating them with solid fundamentals and knowledge of cutting-edge applications. Outcomes of this project potentially enable new material systems for data storage and information processing technologies, with the advantages of high speed, high capacity, and low power consumption.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: All-optical switching of magnetization using ultrafast lasers, without the need for external magnetic fields, has emerged as a frontier topic in contemporary magnetism research. To further advance the field and facilitate potential technology transfer, it is essential to fully understand the underlying mechanisms and reduce both the size of magnetic domains and the required laser power. This CAREER project focused on a new class of hybrid materials consisting of noble metals and ferromagnets, where the tight field confinement and strong optical spin of surface plasmon polaritons could enable low-power, nanoscale, ultrafast all-optical switching of magnetization. The research outcomes of the project resulted in 16 publications in high-impact journals, including Advanced Functional Materials, Advanced Optical Materials, Nano Letters, and ACS Photonics, along with 9 invited talks/seminars and 4 oral/poster presentations by the PI and participating students. The key research highlights of the project are summarized as follows. (1) We comprehensively studied all-optical helicity-dependent switching in hybrid metal-ferromagnet materials composed of magnetic Co/Pt multilayers with a thin Au film on top, which showed robust switching under various laser powers, repetition rates, and scanning rates. (2) We experimentally demonstrated plasmon-enhanced all-optical manipulation of magnetization, achieving an 18.5% reduction in laser power needed to trigger magnetization switching. (3) We developed a multiphysics modeling framework by integrating the Monte Carlo method with full-wave simulations to investigate all-optical helicity-dependent switching of magnetization assisted by plasmonic nanostructures. Simulation results confirmed the feasibility of nanoscale all-optical switching for high-capacity magnetic storage. (4) We built a high-sensitivity pump-probe setup with tunable wavelengths ranging from the visible to the infrared. Using this setup, we investigated electric field tuning of ultrafast demagnetization in bismuth-doped YIG thin films and helicity-induced magnetization dynamics in heavy metal-ferromagnet bilayers.

Broader impacts: Ultrafast, nanoscale, and all-optical control of magnetic materials has the potential to revolutionize magnetic storage, memory, and logic devices, benefiting both the public and the nation. The research findings of the project have significantly advanced our understanding of all-optical switching of magnetization at the extreme spatial and temporal scales. It has also provided new insights into optical spin and optical spin-orbit torque, helping to transform classical plasmonics into the emerging quantum regime. Through this project, PI Liu implemented a long-term education strategy from Grades 7-12 to the graduate level, which was integrally aligned with the PI’s research on nanomaterials and nanophotonics. In particular, this highly interdisciplinary project provided comprehensive training for students. Three Ph.D. students in PI Liu’s group were supported by the project and made significant contributions to the proposed research. They gained fundamental knowledge and developed diverse skills in the areas of magnetic materials, ultrafast optics, nanofabrication, and multiphysics modeling. After graduation, one student joined CGG as a seismic imaging analyst, while two students became postdoctoral research fellows at Polytechnique Montréal and the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. PI Liu also incorporated some fundamental knowledge and recent breakthroughs in plasmonics and magnetic materials into his courses, including EECE 5647 “Nanophotonics,” EECE 7284 “Optical Properties of Matter,” and MATL 7365 “Properties and Processing of Electronic Materials,” for both undergraduate and graduate students.
